acf.intro:
Project Jetson

Welcome to the Project Jetson website.
Jetson is a machine learning-based experiment that provides predictions on the movement(s) of displaced people. This experimental project combines data science, statistical processes, design-thinking techniques, and qualitative research methods. Jetson actively seeks new data sources, new narratives, and new collaborations in order to keep iterating, and improving. It has further underlined the importance of partnership, of collaboration, and of transparency.
acf.first_section:
About the data

The data behind the experiment is central to the overall process. Multiple data inputs are fed into the machine. All data is anonymized and disaggregated per region – and per month. The outcome dataset is a combination of seven years worth of factors that may contribute to forced displacement movement.

Predictors were either suggested by staff within operations and/or refugees themselves. This human-centered approach included focus groups, as well as semi-structured interviews).

The predictor factors are:

  • weather and climate;
  • conflict;
  • market prices;
  • historical population movement patterns (both for internally displaced people and refugees).

Open data is key for the Jetson engine to work. Having technically and legally open data allows humanitarian actors – and others – to make sometimes life-saving decisions to help people, whether those fleeing, or those hosting those who have fled. For example, knowing the number of people arriving at a certain time to a particular region can allow for sufficient preparation, of  for example, contingencies, prepositioning of resources – including human resources. It may also help to identify and attend first to those who are most vulnerable. Jetson represents therefore, a new way of processing and potentially using data. Crucially, it is also an example on how collaboration for open data could potentially, alleviate human suffering and save lives.

The UNHCR Innovation Service wants Project Jetson to become an open process. Creating a functioning prototype that other UNHCR operations and other humanitarian partners could utilize with their own data sets is our version of a fruitful future. For this to be possible, many data sets should be duly processed (e.g. anonymized, cleaned) and openly shared in, ideally, one single data portal. In order to predict, collaboration and partnerships are imperative.  A departure from myopic, territorial approaches of the past, and another step into a future humanitarian response that is multidisciplinary in nature, partnership by default, and whole of society in responsibility and accountability.

Our collaborators and partners:

Our data sources and/or main project partners:

Climate: FAO-SWALIM, WMO, IGAD-ICPAC, UNOSAT, World Bank

Infrastructure: UNOSAT

Conflict: ACLED

Food Security: FAO-FSNAU, FEWES

Population: UNHCR, PRMN

Data Science support: UN Global Pulse, Essex University, Uptake.org

The technology behind:

 

About time series analysis

The experiment consists of measuring multiple data sources and variables to see how changes over time affect the movement of people of concern to UNHCR, particularly refugees and internally displaced people (IDPs). A basic time-series analysis was conducted by machine-learning, in which multiple sources of data/variables are fed into the machine. A time series analysis consists of collecting a series of data points, such as precipitation, changes in markets, and then arranging them with certain time intervals, such as one month, over a period of time. In this case, seven years.

Time series can be analyzed using open source or common statistical commercial software. They are often used by the finance sector, statisticians or econometricians to conduct research. However, for this experiment, we combined time series analysis with machine learning: time series analysis meets computer science.

About machine learning processes:

The machine learning process uses a combination of commonly available commercial software, as well as open source software. Data is fed into the machine, and the machine subsequently attempts to find the best fit, and the best output that explains the behavior of data points that occured in the past, in order to predict the future.

The machine-learning process in this particular experiment has three caveats:

a) the machine does not know the data after either June 2017 or September 2017, and carries out all of its calculations based historical data – without knowing what the actual arrivals were in the subsequent months. This means that the machine was only fed with data until a certain point – even though we had the full dataset until the month in question. We kept this month blank in the machine, in order to serve as a training set. This was done in order to see how well the machine predicted something that already happened, constituting an historical training set.

Additionally, b) the machine is given an algorithm – a formula or a rule – on which to run calculations. However, the algorithm that is given to the machine in order to conduct these calculations does not contain the time variable. Therefore, even though the data is arranged per month, per region, the machine is agnostic of the date, since it is not included in the formula.

The machine then, reads all the data and attempts to find the best fit. These are the best computer-produced models that include all possible data points, and how best they are interrelated to each other. For example, if at a certain point the machine sees more arrivals, it will try to graph how does conflict interrelate with increase in conflict and/or lack of rain. The result of this process are 20 models per region studied, in order to understand the overall region population movement. A total of 380 models were tested in this experiment.

For the model selection, the engine tests all 20 models in a certain month and produces the best examples on which to predict the month. This means that the model that can best predict the arrivals for next month may be the same, but equally could change each month, depending on the region.  

FInally, there c) is a data imputation process behind the engine, conducted automatically by the machine. Imputation means that for any missing value (NA) the machine will carry out an automatic assumption assumption behind the distribution – which means ‘it’ will attempt to calculate the result, even with that missing value, trying to see the interrelation of that missing data value with the other variables that are present.
acf.jetson_models:
About the map

The map was requested by UNHCR’s operation in Somalia as a red-light style of visualization. It portrays the level of critically for movement. Moderate means Jetson is predicting the arrivals of next month within the range of the average arrivals of the past 3 months. High means the machine prediction of arrivals  is higher than the average but less than 100% increase in arrivals, and Critical means is double the average (more than a 100% increase).

About the engine

The graphs above are based on different models that are selected based on seven different statistical or computer-science methods: 1) the best model data that ‘fits’ the historical data (R^2); 2) its mean absolute error (MAE); 3) the multiple imputation by chained equations (MICE) seed value of 50 randomly-selected historical values; 4) the percentage of computer prediction accuracy (ACC); 5) Bayesian information criterion (BIC); Akaike information criterion (AIC) and;  7) a simple pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) for either the past 20 months (ACC/PCC) and/or the overall seven years of data (rest).

The model selection methods mentioned above attempt to measure the accuracy of future predictions, and are the difference between the future predictive arrivals vs. actual arrivals. In short, they describe the margin of error of arrivals provided by the machine vs. reality. For example, the higher the MAE, the less accurate the prediction. R^2 is the value of how close the model is based on historical data. The closer (or fit) the model, the higher the value, with 1.0 being the most ideal fit. Each model will have different results of each of the five measures.
acf.second_section:
Project Jetson Version 1.0

What’s new?

Version 1.0 is the first public version of Jetson. The previous versions focused only on the concept of the predictive analytics engine. This version provides functioning models that predict each regions arrival with between a 60% to 110% accuracy – depending upon the region. The more missing data in a particular region, the less accurate is the machine to calculate results.

In version 1.0, we have improved, and added:

  • Automation processes (back-end);
  • Map with level of criticality of displacement;
  • Included end-user feedback;
  • Github site;
  • And a Communications strategy to share results with the general public.

Design:  Version 1.0 of Jetson provides a lighter, faster, and a simpler user interface with the key focus on predicted monthly arrival figures rather than a simulation of population from previous versions. We need web-based tools and applications to be inclusive, including to those with a lower internet bandwidth.

Automation Process:  50% of processes completed in previous versions of Jetson were done by humans but are now performed automatically, by the machine. Different computer applications combine (see Github), to free up time for further development and expansion of prediction regions. We are still refining the processes to be almost semi-automated. Humans are still required to press the run button to execute the various processes.

We are currently working on:
The next steps for Project Jetson are to improve the software deployment of the service and introduce new prediction regions.

  • With the University of Essex and UNOSAT, we are working on a machine learning-based classification model for climate and conflict variables;
  • Our team aims to have the predictive analytics software as a complete package that can be installed and run locally, by other UNHCR operations or partners.

The eventual complete Jetson package will consist of the following processes:

  • Data collection from multiple online sources;
  • Transforming data into-machine readable formats and pushing it online;
  • Running of the predictive analytics algorithms;
  • Analysing the model’s results;
  • Running the analysed statistical correlations to compare model’s accuracy vs. actual figures;
  • Detecting the arrival range (predicted population arrivals);
  • Deciding on best model according to human decision-making rules;
  • Communicating and visualizing the results for the operation.

The deployable package will also include a model monitoring element that picks the best algorithm for the next month and detects the population arrival range, according to analysed correlations. The arrival range on the website is the result of this process.

The automation effort of all technical processes involved will be continuing, therefore minimising human decision making and ‘interference’ where not relevant. This will leave more resources for the Jetson team to focus on top line decisions for the predicted arrivals and the project in general.

faqs.faq_content:
One of the most pressing challenges for humanitarian agencies in trying to predict population movements is the information gap that exists when people move from one place to another. This is particularly challenging during emergencies when fluid or rapid movements make it challenging for humanitarian actors to track and estimate arrivals, and departures. Consequently, this challenge affects planning, emergency preparedness, funding of assistance, and operational services. The challenge is exacerbated by:

  1. Lack of access to territory: referring to regions with ongoing violent conflict, to occupied territories and/or geographical areas where humanitarian actors are not present or access is denied;
  2. Lack of resources: lack of financial or human resources to deploy enumerators to collect data from specific sources or geographical locations;
  3. Lack of informants: collecting data from specific sources or a particular group can bias the data;
  4. Lack of validation: sometimes information verification is conducted only by participant observation (visual) and/or the data provided by the informants could be partial or inaccurate for diverse number of reasons;
  5. A lack of expertise, experience, tools, techniques, systems. We need to be able to attract and hire those with unique experience into our system in order to take our system forwards. These are typically those with less experience, but with more defined expertise in areas that humanitarian organisations do not currently have, or in some cases, do not even know they require.

faqs.faq_title: What is Jetson technology based on?
faqs.faq_content: On forecasting statistical techniques and open source-based applications for modeling. The scripts and the aggregated and anonymized datasets will be published in UNHCR github once the experiment is finished.

faqs.faq_title: Why aren’t you predicting the entire world?
faqs.faq_content: We are in development stage of the project and looking into adding more regions and situations to the experiment. Each region and country have different elements as predictors, therefore there is a need to collect specific data according to context.

1. The project is focused only in the population flow, both across borders (refugees) and internally (IDPs). This means the main research purpose is to measure changes in the population in an specific period of time (e.g. a month).
  2. There is not one single major cause of forced displacement. There are many causes (variables) and an infinite combination of these variables, along with behavioral human patterns that lead to forced displacement. The objective of the model is not to find the cause (why?) but to explain how are people moving (patterns).
  3. This project attempts to find interesting and meaningful patterns in data by making assumptions from the data our partners are providing, particularly when data is not available, or is incomplete.
  4. Some of the assumptions do not need a model to tell that the assumption is correct. Building a model goes beyond identifying the assumptions’ characteristics (e.g. we do not need a model to know people are forced to flee due to conflict). However, the model attempts to find the best combination that could predict the target variable, in this case: population flow numbers and geographical locations, in an specific period of time.

faqs.faq_title: What are the variables for Jetson?
faqs.faq_content:
• Current number of Persons of Concern (PoC) per region per month
  • Departures number of PoC per region per month
  • Arrivals number of PoC per region per month
  • Number of fatalities per region per month
  • Number of violent conflict incidents per region per month
  • River levels per river per month
  • River discharge per river per month
  • Rainfall average per region per month
  • Water drum price per region per month
  • Local goat Price per region per month

The data behind the engine is anonymized, aggregated per month and per region and complies with UNHCR Data Protection policy standards

The models used for each region in the engine represent the top 3 best ‘fit’ functions that can explain the behaviour of seven years of historical data. The target variable (y) is number of arrivals for each region.

The model is trained with data until 30 June 2017 and the date that the predictive algorithm was built is 1 September 2017.

acf.third_section:
A final note on Jetson, and its future

Jetson is only possible because managers provide, and actively encourage experimental approaches. Jetson is only possible because we can attract, and hopefully retain talent that brings a unique, diversity of thought and experience. Jetson is only possible because inclusive design, validation, and iteration processes have been embraced. Jetson is only possible because of an active pursuance of partnership. The future of of Jetson will also require an ability to scale, and to embrace decision making that is based on data and evidence. That requires us to make Jetson more accessible, better understood, and useable, in some case by people whom this will be uncomfortable for. More on this later.

acf.technical_specs_intro:
Technical Specifications

Discover the technical specifications of UNHCR’s first predictive analytics experiment, from the datasets format to our code’s repositories. This section is intended to describe the steps taken to create a humanitarian predictive analytics project, with applied computer science research, as well as the steps taken to develop and improve the experiment.

sections.title: Project Jetson
sections.text:
UNHCR’s Innovation Service has been working to understand the intrinsic nexus between climate change, violent conflict, and forced displacement. Using supervised machine learning, UNHCR designed Project Jetson, an engine that is fed data and uses trained models to predict the displacement of persons in Somalia.

Forced displacement is a complex phenomenon. Mathematical evidence shows that there are certain factors, such as food insecurity and violent conflict, as well as the appeal of the destination region, in terms of price, distance, and stability, that cause people to move. Certain combinations of these factors are more likely to make people move than others.

Project Jetson is an on-going experiment to discover, understand, and measure the specific factors that cause, indicate or exacerbate the forced displacement of Somalis.

Project Jetson gives UNHCR and other humanitarian organizations the potential to become more proactive in their response efforts — a transformation that could significantly improve on-the-ground relief services and more importantly the lives of those who are forcibly displaced.

sections.title: Success Metrics
sections.text:
For a project like this, we develop a strategic vision document aimed to create some metrics of success of the project.  The goals are aligned to UNHCR Innovation work: 1) research new methods, 2) facilitate and foster collaboration and organizational culture around innovation and 3) improve tools that create awareness of decision-making processes with data to improve protection outcomes.

The following metrics of success have been developed to evaluate the overall performance of the project:

  • Solve the challenge given by a UNHCR field operation: predict the number of arrivals, both IDPs and refugees in certain regions of Somalia and the cross-border south region of Ethiopia (Dollo Ado)
  • Improve research on predictive analytics for protection purposes in the humanitarian space
  • Develop a methodology and its related tools for forced displacement predictions.
  • Predict in advance, with a certain degree of accuracy, the number of arrivals in a determined location
  • And last but not least, understanding the linkages between machines and human decision making in the humanitarian space.

sections.title: About the Data
sections.text:
Open Data

The main central component of a predictive analytics project is open data. Open data as defined by Open Data Handbook is data that is legally open and technically open.

In the case of Jetson, legally open data refers to the datasets that partners share either:

  • Publicly on their websites or in a humanitarian data broker website (e.g. OCHA HDX)
  • Bilaterally shared, derived from the principle of international cooperation (e.g. operational data shared on a joint-service or research between UN System agencies)
  • Via formal/legal data sharing agreement (e.g. Memorandum of Understanding, MoU or similar agreements).

Technically open data for the project is data that is a machine-readable format (ideally a tabular format, csv, json, xls) and/or that has a public API to be extracted automatically, with a certain time periodicity which, in the case of Project Jetson is every month.

Having these two main components is difficult in areas where there is no humanitarian access due to violent conflict or other reasons or that time/resource capacity to collect is limited or completely non-existent. These are some of the greatest data challenges of the humanitarian sector vis-à-vis other sectors to have datasets ready for predictive analysis.

Data Protection

Additionally, and given the nature of our organizational mandate, all the datasets used in this experiment have been anonymized and aggregated in order to comply with UNHCR data protection policy. For this reason, the scripts and API calls are only referring to the anonymized and aggregated copy of the original datasets.

The original datasets – as provided by the partners with their respective data protection clauses – are intact and stored in a UNHCR internal corporate repositories. They can be deleted at any time by the request of the respective data providers.

Nevertheless, and conscious of the aforementioned limitations, our partners and data sources have been key in the development of this experiment by providing us with either timely and open data or by publishing their data in their respective websites. Additionally, they have provided us with advice on improvements on methodology and techniques to conduct our experiment.

sections.title: Jetson Data
sections.text:
The variables selected to conduct this experiment, represent the main influencers of the different regions of population movement. In order to select what variables to input into Jetson experiment, several steps from innovation methodologies were taken. For example, using the principles of human-centered design, variables were selected according to different reasons such as:

  • Were originally assumed by conducting an initial literature review of the operational context
  • Were suggested by UNHCR staff and/or the field operation with extensive field experience in that particular region
  • Were suggested by persons of concern themselves, particularly refugees

According to them, the most influential (dependent) variables – and therefore the datasets collected – to understand forced displacement from Somalia are:

  • Violent conflict: is defined in ACLED codebook – which is one of the main violent conflict data sources in the region. We included all the violent events and demonstrations or in other words excluded all non-violent actions (event type: strategic developments). We used two main variables from this data source: the sum amount of violent incidents per month per region and the amount of fatalities (deaths) per month per region.  ACLED is the only data source for Jetson with a public API, and the call for violent conflict (e.g. incidents) would be the following:

acled_incidents = acled[(acled.event_type!=”Strategic developments”).groupby([“admin1”, ‘month_year’]).count()[[‘data_id’]]

  • Climate & Weather anomalies: climate and weather predictive analytics is a rigorous science with many meteorology and environmentally-based methods. In order for us to keep the experiment as simple as possible we analysed two main variables, as a proxy for climate and weather anomalies considering that they are some of the main weather/climate anomalies that disrupt livelihoods in the region:
    • Rain patterns: provided to us by FAO SWALIM team, originally publicly available in this site, later on shared to us via email (excel tables with gauge sensors data).
    • River levels: publicly available data by FAO SWALIM we originally built a parser for extracting the data from the river level graphs.
  • Market prices: were suggested to be included in this experiment by refugees themselves via key informant interviews. They highlighted the importance of two commodities for their livelihoods: water drum prices and [local] goat market prices, this latter being a proxy for movement. This is due to the fact that refugees stated that goats are a sensitive product to extreme weather conditions. Prior fleeing they sell them in order to their trip/tribe dying on the road due to lack of water or pasture to feed on. This creates a ripple effect on the local market of supply/demand for the local commodity. The market prices are collected by FAO FSNAU team.

Recently, FAO SWALIM and FSNAU teams joined forces and collated the climate, weather and market datasets datasets together in a single dashboard (registration required):  FAO FSNAU Early Warning/Early Action in Somalia

And of course, the target variable (independent variable, y) which is:

  • Forced displacement: internal displacement collected by UNHCR-Protection and Return Monitoring Network (PRMN) partnership within Somalia and cross-border refugee movement , using registration data from UNHCR Dollo Ado team in Ethiopia.

sections.title: Jetson Command:  Introduction to technical specs
sections.text:
Jetson development is divided into five different components:

  1. Data: the data is the main component of the project. Jetson datasets represent the collection effort of both humanitarian and development sector partners to gather evidence on the different variables that could influence forced displacement in the Somali context. They are a recollection of seven years of the different variables datasets, aggregated and anonymized on a monthly basis presented in a time-series format. More information about the type of datasets and the different variables in the About the Data Section. The width of the dataset is 153 different variables and the length is the total of years times the number of months (e.g. from January 2010 until June 2017, is 90).
  2. Modeling applications: this is a flexible component in Jetson and it varies depending on data protection requirements. We have tested both open-source and also out-of-the-box (including licensed software) applications for modeling purposes. The application minimum five tech specs are:
    1. Supports integration with tabular applications (e.g. excel/google sheets) and has a python/JS/R API;
    2. Ability to conduct multivariate time series forecasting, defining time lags, and windows of time to perform machine learning of the past and project to future values.
    3. Possibility to run predictions both locally (for data security purposes, small scale testing) as well as run them in the cloud;
    4. Contains fairly good interpretability elements to understand machine calculations [and avoid the A.I. black-box concept] and;
    5. Ideally, that has a ‘feedback loop’ element, this means that with new inputs in data, the machine adapts the new data points into the future predictions.

Experiment #1: predicting one-month in advance

Data: same datasets (see About Data section)


Modelling applications: we utilized a combination for this experiment Eureqa (modeling app) + optimus prime (interpretability) + R-shiny (visualization)

  • Eureqa: non-deterministic models based on genetic and evolutionary algorithms, a tool developed by Cornell’s Artificial Intelligence team. For the software to start evaluating solutions, different parameters have to be defined and the data to be inserted in the system on a clean and targeted way.
  • Python apps: Optimus prime (optimus.py): A “translator” for the eureqa output to an R function that grabs the date needed to produce the “forecasted” value. This part was more dedicated to automation, resulting in predictions for all the regions for all the models produced by Eureqa.
  • R-Shiny apps: modeler.R, engine.R: A visual way to view the predictions, per region for the models that are performing the best.

Data Preparation: Inputs for the machine

Building functions for modelling

For testing the different applications we have built tested several functions with different lags and and/or different combinations of variables (e.g. eliminating some to have a less lengthy processing time) for modelling purposes.

Lags

We produced 2 functions for each region, one function with a minus -1 lag (one month in advance prediction) and one function with minus -2 lag. This is a total of 36 functions: one with minus-1 and another one with minus-2, corresponding to each region of Somalia (18 regions), plus Dollo Ado counted as 1 region (“region” 19).

Building Training + Testing sets

For the first experiment a total of 418 models were produced coming from  22 per each region of Somalia (18 regions), plus Dollo Ado counted as 1 region (19 regions). From those 22, 21 were built with a minus -1 lag and, 1 was built with a minus -2 lag.

How we built the training sets : june 2017 or sep 2017 

The evaluation of models can be found here and the sensitive map of the weights of different variables in the different regions can be found here.

X missing app/graph/heatmap  here

Figure 4: Sensitivity Map, derived from functions most prevalent variables

Transformation scripts: the transformation scripts are a interpretability element for those applications who provide a model (function) as output of their calculations, like Eureqa. We built a  python application, called optimus prime (optimus.py) to transform the function the model functions into prediction numbers in a time-series format, this means transforming a formula into numerical variables.

Example of one model (function generated by the modelling application):

Jubbada_Hoose_CurrentRegion = max(max(delay(Nugaal_CurrentRegion, 7)*smm(delay(Togdheer_Conflict, 1), 6), max(smm(delay(Hiiraan_BeforeRegion, 1), 16)*log(wma(delay(Hiiraan_CurrentRegion, 1), 3)) + max(delay(Nugaal_CurrentRegion, 11), max(0.330162338655957*delay(Sool_Fatalities, 1)*mma(delay(Galgaduud_FutureRegion, 1), 3), sma(delay(Bay_rain, 1), 11)*smm(delay(Bay_rain, 1), 9))) – delay(Galgaduud_Conflict, 14)*wma(delay(Shabeellaha_Dhexe_rain, 1), 2), 6.04475718368644e-5*delay(Banadir_BeforeRegion, 1)*delay(Shabeellaha_Dhexe_BeforeRegion, 1))), wma(delay(Woqooyi_Galbeed_CurrentRegion, 1), 2))

 

Output of transformation scripts (machine calculations):

Figure 1: Time-series formatted, machine calculations

 Model Evaluation

  1. The Engine & Model Selector: both the engine and the modeler are visual representations of the backend work of Jetson. They are two R-shiny based applications to interpret different elements:
    1. Model Selector (a.k.a. modeler): the modeler is a R-shiny app that contains some of the performance metrics of the models after the machine has made its new predictions calculations. The performance metrics are both statistical and computer-science based metrics and help to select new models every month, given that new inputs of past data will change the output of the following month (feedback loop). Even though the models are fixed (static modeling), the output for every month changed according to the different variable weights, and therefore the need to evaluate the performance of the machine’s new calculations.

Model selector then portrays in a visual way the following performance metrics of

the model’s new outputs:

      1. Statistics:  Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC), and a simple Pearson Correlation between machine predicts vs. actual arrivals, for the last 20-months of data available.
      2. Computer science: we measure three variables in this component
        1. One is the percentage of [machine] correct classification (PCC), which is a measure to take the proportion of correctly “predicted” months vs. the actual arrivals.
        2. The second one is the occurrence of top “influencers”, coming from the sensitivity map of the most repeated variables in the output model function, to be able to identify.
        3. And the third, is the Multivariate Imputation by Chained Equations (MICE) algorithm, with a random seed of 50% of the data.

Figure 2: Model Selector app

Model Selection (human element):

    1. Engine:  the engine is the output visualization of the models. It is composed by the 18 regions of Somalia, plus Dollo Ado region (southern border, Ethiopia). It portrays the 3 out-performing models in a graph – based on the metrics mentioned above – per month per region. The engine changes the models according to the new monthly predictions.

Figure 3: Engine app

  1. Map: the final visualization of the predictions and the historical predictions per region. It portrays the level of influx in a certain region with the following thresholds established by UNHCR Somalia operation:
    1. Low: if the region experiences a normal influxing, averaging the 3 past months,
    2. Medium: averaging the past 3 months, if the particular region experiences an increase of influx up to 50% and less than 99% (less than the double).
    3. High: if the region experiences an increase of population influx equal to 100% (double) or more, averaging the past 3 months.

Having the historical predictions also give an overall evaluation of the different models used to understand for example if there are regions whose movement is due to seasonality or modus vivendi (e.g. pastoralists) or if there is a nexus between conflict, climate and displacement, to be able to predict it. This is the work we are expanding through our research partners: UN Global Pulse and HRBDT Centre of the University of Essex.
